caption: A very beautiful museum to visit, it has lots of good collections of art. The museum is really beautiful and you should visit if you live in Paris to know more about art and culture. The surrounding areas are also beautiful. Right now there is a very beautiful temporary exhibition and it's a must see.

Not a free museum. Very mini, with only 13 rooms. The staff was indifferent, except for the gentleman standing guard at the door. Compared with other museums in Paris with rich collections, I have to say that the tickets are too expensive. I spent half an hour looking at all the exhibits I could.

This sweet little museum is worth it for the quaintest street, and “home” it sits on, and in!  It houses the private collection of the founders of Samaritaine, the gorgeous department store! There are most definitely some gems, but it isn’t as interesting as the others around it.  If you want to escape the hustle and want something unique, duck in here!  I am totally enthralled by the street it’s on.

I read it’s free to enter but when I arrived, they told me the admission is 9 euros. It’s a beautiful and intriguing museum, well worth the money and time. However, most displays are in French, I just used a translation app to read the signs.

Came here randomly one morning and it was very beautiful and amazing. The staff were very nice and it was not overcrowded. There are a lot of beautiful things in this collection. I would definitely visit this again.

Came here for the journée du patrimoine and was disappointed. Had to pay to get in when almost places are free. Staff was unwelcoming. Museum is small and there is little space for display, lots of heavy lighting and no ventilation makes it hot.  Would only return for a specific exhibit.
Not free (as I had read in a guidebook and reviews here from a year ago said).  I paid the 9 euros.  Sweet little museum but not worth 9 euros.

A superb collection of Grand Tour paintings and collectibles as well other 18th Century high art I n the Marais. A relaxed atmosphere in which you can stand nose to canvas with Italian and French greats. The museum is free to enter.

It's a charming museum nestled into a court in the Marais. I visited it for the « Luxe de poche » exhibition. The exhibition is open until late September, but it’s worth visiting for its permanent collection.

A small free museum in le marais. It’s nice to walk around and see the private collection and the building is also interesting. The museum is not accessible to wheelchair users unfortunately and you do have to go up and down stairs.

Our spontaneous decision to visit Musée Cognacq-Jay turned out to be a highlight of our Parisian adventure. Tucked away in a picturesque part of Paris, this museum is a treasure trove of art and history.  The museum itself is a revelation, especially considering its modest size. We were captivated by the diverse collection of paintings, sculptures, and artefacts, each with its own story and charm. The variety and quality of the exhibits were unexpected, offering a rich visual feast.  We spent a delightful hour wandering through the museum, admiring every painting and item. The intimate setting allowed us to appreciate the details of each piece, making the experience both personal and profound.  What’s remarkable about Musée Cognacq-Jay is that it offers this wonderful experience free of charge. It’s a rare find in a city filled with expensive attractions.  We wholeheartedly recommend a visit to Musée Cognacq-Jay for anyone looking for a beautiful and serene cultural experience in Paris. It’s a perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of the city, offering a glimpse into a world of artistic elegance and historical depth.

The people who started that big expensive mask, La Samaritane, were really friendly philanthropists and art collecters of 18th century romantic pieces! Housed in one of the oldest mansions in Paris and free to the public, you can see everything without feeling overwhelmed!:) We went slowly through the museum and came out in maybe 1.5 hours at most. Unique pieces and it is fun to daydream about living in such a fancy house. I also loved learning about the couple who opened the exquisite mall.  There is also a free restroom on site!

Google Maps says it's free, but the entrance costs 9€. The museum is small and easy to navigate. Unfortunately, there's no English description of the objects, but the interactive displays were a nice touch to help understand some of the exhibits.

It's free and can be enjoyed in just half an hour makes it a perfect stop for a quick dose of culture. The staff adds to the experience with their warm and friendly demeanor, and the art, paintings, and historical treasures are a visual treat.

When visiting the Marais and Paris in general, I think it’s always a wonderful idea to visit the smaller museums to get a more intimate side of the city. And sometimes, they’re even free admission.  This museum is free to enter. Once a 17th century home of a local aristocrat, now is an art museum with paintings, sculptures and furniture. The layout is much like an aristocrats home from the time period. There is a small section dedicated to erotic art, so be sure to watch out for that in case it’s not your preference.

The Cognacq-Jay Museum, in the heart of the Marais, recreates the atmosphere of a Parisian residence in the Age of Enlightenment.  Located in a beautiful 16th-century mansion, between courtyard and garden, the museum houses an exceptional set of 18th-century works of art: paintings by Boucher, Chardin and Fragonard, drawings by Watteau, sculptures, stamped furniture and precious objects (jewellery, tobacconists, Saxony porcelain...).  Ernest Cognacq and his wife Louise Jay, founders of the La Samaritaine department store, bequeathed the collections to the City of Paris in 1928.  Rates and terms  This is another “FREE” all year round Museum in Paris.  Free permanent collections. Paid temporary exhibitions. The Paris Museums card gives access to all the temporary exhibitions of the museums of the City of Paris, with unlimited access and without queueing, for one year.  Lovely small museum with some stunning oil paintings. Worth a visit.
A lovely small but quiet museum with beautiful works of art from the 18th century.. attractively displayed and very atmospheric!

This museum is free and open for general public. It is owned by the city and thats why it is free. Although the museum is small, 3 floors with mainly 9 rooms, it bloats a nice selection of pieces of art : Asian deco, European and mainly french classic paintings, European deco, other exciting paintings from famous artists such Vigee Le Brun , Bouchee and Rembrandt. Everything was reviously owned by Cognacq-Jay: a couple of Art Lovers and patreons - Paris inherited their Hotel privé (a mansion from the 17th century in le Marais) and everything in it. Now, the mansion lives as a public free museum. I highly reccomend you give it a chance if you are nearby. You will get a chance to experience of a Parisian mansion from the 17th century, and appreciate the same art as the Cognaq-Jays.
Beautiful there was not much of queue there were not that many ehvibitipns open but what I did see I really enjoyed. The staff were kind.

The Musee Cognacq-Jay is one of fourteen City of Paris Museums, housed in former Hotel Doren building in The Marais. It is located near to Musee Carnavalet and makes a nice complement to its larger peer. This museum is free to visit and well worth your time if you are interested in seeing 18th century furnishing, paintings and other artworks. There are some later works included in this collection as well.  The Musee Cognacq-Jay is the result of a wonderful collection gathered by Ernest Cognacg and his wife Marie-Louise Jay between 1900 and 1925. Upon the death of Cognacq in 1928, the collection was bestowed to the city of Paris where it became a museum, originally located on Blvd. des Capucines. The museum collection was moved to the present site, the historic Hotel Doren, in 1990 and this is where it can be found today.  When visiting the Musee Cognacq-Jay, you can explore twenty panelled rooms, each well decorated with historic paintings, porcelain, elegant furniture and other works of art. Works by numerous French and foreigner artists can be found including the likes of La Tour, Lemoyne, Chardin, Fragonard, Boucher, Degas as well as Rembrandt and Cannaletto amongst others.  Overall, we'd suggest first prioritising a visit to nearby Musee Carnavalet and then paying visit to Musee Cognacq-Jay if time (and energy) permits. It is a nice museum to visit if you intend to spend time in The Marais and can comfortably be explored in 45 minutes before moving onward.

We went to see the Louis-Léopold Boilly exhibition here which was fantastic. A wonderful way to start a visit to Paris. (Note this exhibition was not free). He's an extraordinary painter from between the French revolutions, full of humour and way ahead of his time in many ways (he put himself in his paintings and broke the 3rd wall, and used optical techniques to great effect).  Suggestion: use google translate to convert info boards to English images. There were no translations for this exhibition.  There were some quite interesting items in the permanent exhibition, but I don't know what the Museum has when there is no special exhibition. It's normally free though, so nothing to lose on visiting. There's a small and very serene courtyard to sit in, which would be especially welcome in warm weather.
One of my favourite museum in Paris not very big and not crowded (yet)!
Disappointing museum. A little dusty, windows need cleaning. It’s very small, paintings are average, nothing remarkable.
Amazing small museum free to visit all year long. It offers you the taste of 18th century.
Some nice artwork such as paintings, furniture and porcelain are exhibited. The building is nicely decorated. Free admission. Helpful staff and they have lockers for bags.
The is small hidden gem. The museum is free but Always almost empty . Nice place in le Marais to comtemplate on this "private" collecrion of art
Attention visitors: as of September 2024 this museum is not free at all and do have a fee entrance as it’s now displayed an especial exhibition.

Little free museum in The heart of Le Marais. The House of Cognac-Jay has a collection of XVIII th century art that includes Canaletto, Guardi and Rembrandt. Gardens are open until 17.00 on rue Payenne (you cannot reach them from the inside of the house).
Free museum with a rather small amount of paintings but it was still nice for a stroll and worth a visit.

Lovely museum that explores the XVIIIe century in art and the personal collection of Cognacq and his wife. Free entry for permanent collection. Michel who works at the museum was so kind and helpful! He was also knowledgeable about the artwork and history, I’ve never met someone as passionate working at a museum. I highly recommend this place to visit.
Lovely museum displaying few very good quality art pieces
The museum is beautiful but very small. The little objects of art that they have  here are rather unique.
Pleasant surprise. Free entry. Collection includes Rembrandt and Canaletto

The staff was friendly. The permanent  collection  is first class and free to see. The courtyard was a nice escape from afternoon rain showers and  allowed time to plan. It would also be a good place to get away from the sun. There is a public toilet in the basement. There is a Rembrandt, from when he was young maybe 20, Balaam's Donkey free to see and enjoy if you are willing  to  climb some stsirs, because there are many steps to climb.
Nice small museum, expect to spend ~30 min. Entrance is free.
Nice little museum. Very quick to visit.
Wonderful gem of a museum with a great courtyard cafe. The staff of both are kind and multilingual.
Not worth the visit! Site said free entry, but we were asked to pay!… was a very short visit and not worth the price of admission
